instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2915: What is 820-2915? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.D6990: What is D6990? Diode sitting between PPBUS_G3H/PP18V5 charger voltage and PP3V42_G3H power supply input, can die and cause PP3V42_G3H to be missing and have no input voltage. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .
definitions.R7005: What is R7005? resistor between charger and CHGR_DCIN pin of ISL6259, if CHGR_DCIN is low then this resistor is probably blown. When PPBUS_G3H is low or missing this is something to check if your model has CHGR_DCIN along R7005. .
definitions.R7021: What is R7021? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7022: What is R7022? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.R6990: What is R6990? Resistor between charger voltage and input to PP3V42_G3H power supply on Macbooks from around the year 2012. This resistor blows when C6990 has shorted to ground or U6990 has shorted to ground, and will result in PP3V42_G3H missing and the magsafe charger not having a light since PP3V42_G3H is necessary for the SMC to turn on and the onewire circuit to turn on..
definitions.C6990: What is C6990? Capacitor to ground on input to PP3V42_G3H power supply. PP3V42_G3H power supply turns 18.5v from charger or 8.5v-12.5v PPBUS_G3H from the battery into PP3V42_G3H. This capacitor can short to ground and keep PP3V42_G3H from turning on which would keep the machine from having a light on the magsafe charger.
definitions.C6905: What is C6905? Capacitor to ground on charger input, if this shorts to ground the charger will not put out any power. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.ADAPTER_EN: What is ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER: What is SMC_ADAPTER? SMC_ADAPTER_EN is an abbreviation of SMC_ADAPTER_EN, which enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.CPU_VCORE: What is CPU_VCORE? Power rail for the CPU. If this is missing the machine will act braindead. .
definitions.R7051: What is R7051? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7052: What is R7052? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No power on with green light
threads.message:
This repair started with no power on and no lights on the magsafe.

After reading through some threads and testing the power rails I replaced the <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and now I get a green light but no boot, fans etc.

I've gone back and forth so many times with the 1 wire and other voltages that I think I lost my mind completely.

Here is what I get now for voltages. I know this is a lot but I wanted to give too much info vs. to little.

Thank you,
Chris

Pin 2 -  16.80V
Pin 5 - 3.42V

<CAPACITOR>C6905</CAPACITOR> 16.83V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No power on with green light
threads.message: Voltage on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> (F7040), resistance between pin 17/18 and 27/28 from <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>......

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No power on with green light
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No power on with green light
threads.message: Are you using a REAL GENUINE APPLE 85W charger?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No power on with green light
threads.message:
It's old and used and certainly looks like it. It has the soft rubber cables. It really does look authentic. I tried 2 others. 85W authentic Apple.

The biggest question I have is the 16.5 volts not 18.5.

Could this be the <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> is a bad chip or I did a poor job placing it?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No power on with green light
threads.message: 16.5V would suggest you are using a 60W charger as 85W should put out 18.5. Is <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> high?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No power on with green light
threads.message: Is SMC-<SIGNAL>ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> high... by this do you mean is there voltage?  I have 3.4v at test point TP[1]<SIGNAL>SMC_RX_L</SIGNAL> .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No power on with green light
threads.message: I have tried 4 different 85W OEM chargers and 3 different magsafe DC power boards and I get the 16.5 volts from all of them testing at J6900

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No power on with green light
threads.message:
I asked for <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER</SIGNAL> enable, please explain what <SIGNAL>SMC_RX_L</SIGNAL> has to do with that? Test at <RESISTOR>R5085</RESISTOR>.

I bet you are using China special chargers, that say 85W but are just 60W ones.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No power on with green light
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R5085</RESISTOR> pin 1 is 3.43V

I've been repairing Macs for years (only recently component level) and I sell the chargers so please trust me when I say i know the difference. One of the chargers I used was my own from my MBP.
If need be, I will go to best buy and buy another brand new one. 

At least this help me understand that I'm not entirely insane. :)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No power on with green light
threads.message:
So I put the logic board back into the system. I decided to try and do an SMC reset hoping for the best.

What I get is:
It charges the battery, the charge indicator is amber and charging.
I try to power it up and get the sound of the CD loading but no video (no the backlight isnt out) no indication other than the CD that the power button was pressed.
The SMC reset turns the charge light green briefly.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No power on with green light
threads.message:
Uhm, so it does power on......
Fans spinning? CPU Vcore present?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No power on with green light
threads.message: No fans or other sings of life other than hearing the CD cycle.  I checked <SIGNAL>CPU_VCORE</SIGNAL> at <CAPACITOR>C7513</CAPACITOR> pin 1 an dhave 12.6V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No power on with green light
threads.message:
Now I am back to no lights on the charger. I'll start back at square one and try again. I guess this is the pain and struggle of being a newbie........
Thank you for your previous help. I'm sure I'll be back with more questions.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No power on with green light
threads.message:
I have been working on this again after a couple of days away from it to clear my head... very frustrating.. The issue now is low voltage on <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR> - <SIGNAL>CHGR_SGATE</SIGNAL>.  I only get 1.6V on pin 26 of <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.  I have replaced <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> 2 times because it seems like this is where I lose the power. 
On <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR> I lose the power on the "Reverse-Current Protection" side.
<TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR> the Inrush-limiter side I get 16.09 volts. so this seems good.

Can you please offer me some ides?
Thank you.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No power on with green light
threads.message: 1.6V on pin 26 is great, it means it is turning on half of <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR> at least. Same should happen on pin 1 so there is the problem. Either dead <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> or <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR> or some resistor/trace around <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No power on with green light
threads.message:
Probably that damned <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>... I'll swap out the <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR> and recheck the resistors around it.
Thank you.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No power on with green light
threads.message:
Replace <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR>. I now have 5v that drops to 1.2v on <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR>, Replaced <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> 3rd time with one from another board. The new ones i have been using dont seem to make a difference.

Now I am back to having low voltage on pin 3 of <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>. 
<RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR> 16.2v
<RESISTOR>R7051</RESISTOR> 1.2
<RESISTOR>R7052</RESISTOR> 1.3

<RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR> 1.2v
<RESISTOR>R7022</RESISTOR> 1.4v

<RESISTOR>R7010</RESISTOR>  has 16.3v on pin1 and 1.7v on pin 2..

I really feel like I'm just going in circles..

I replace <RESISTOR>R7010</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7011</RESISTOR> and <CAPACITOR>C7010</CAPACITOR>. The resistors because they would'nt read correctly in circuit. <RESISTOR>R7010</RESISTOR> was 13.8ohm in circuit and ok out of circuit. <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR> was 28.2ohm in circuit and 20 in circuit.

*sigh*

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No power on with green light
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R7010</RESISTOR>/11 is a simple resistor divider and if you do the calculation it should have about 3.7V to <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>. Remove <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and I bet the voltage will come up to 3.7V. So Badly soldered or dead <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> pulling ACIN down.
Green light should not be present at this time as ACIN is too low.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No power on with green light
threads.message: So does this mean that yet another... 4-5 <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> chip is bad?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No power on with green light
threads.message:
Badly soldered or a bad <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>. My soldering may not be a work of art but I have checked each solder point for a secure solder and pressed down firmly on the chip as I was placing it (as Louis suggested in a video) so,... Either the <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> is bad (this last one a used one) or my solder work sucks and I can't see it.

Option C: Is there another component that will blow out <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> if it's bad or shorted? Could I be blowing each of the <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> chips I am installing?

Thank you

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No power on with green light
threads.message:
and yes, I lost the green light sooooo... I somehow blew the <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> or something else blew it.

learning these circuits is such a pain in the arse but the good side of this is that this is how we learn to understand the circuitry in a very comprehensive way. :)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No power on with green light
threads.message: Replace <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR>/35. Check <RESISTOR>R7001</RESISTOR>/7005 and resistance between pins 17/18, 27/28.
